metadata.title: Studying antimicrobial activity of carbon nanotubes decorated with metal-doped ZnO hybrid materials

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text:
Carbon nanomaterials like single wall nanotubes (SWNTs) andmulti wall nanotubes (MWNTs) can be depicted as hollow structures, which are constituted by rolling graphene layers into a tube [1]. CNTs have attracted significant attention for their enormous potential concerning application as biomaterials in the last decade [2–4]. CNTs have been recognized asmildly toxic tomost living cells, equally for eukaryotic and essential for prokaryotic cells [5, 6]. CNTs, specially SWNTs have a significantly higher antimicrobial activity in comparison with other carbon nanomaterials [7]. The antimicrobial effect of SWNTs andMWNTswere first investigated by Kang et al [8]. In their study, Kang et al demonstrate that SWNTs reveal a higher antimicrobial performance than MWNTs,maybe resulting from their smaller size that assistsmembrane disruption and gives a larger surface area [9]. The dispersing capability of CNTs in polar and nonpolar solvents was presented to have a critical influence on the antimicrobial efficacy of CNTs, since the direct contact of CNTswith target pathogenswere desired [10]. Purification onCNTs and functionalizationwere usually utilized to improve the bactericidal action of CNTs by enhancing the dispersing capability of CNTs in aqueousmedia [11]. As shown in previous studies, carbon nanotubes at low concentrations demonstrated no antimicrobial effect against gram-negative and grampositive bacterial cells [12].
Among various nanoparticles, the strong antibacterial activity of zinc oxide (ZnO)nanoparticles has attractedmore attention against awide range of bacteria. The reactive oxygen species (ROS) produced by photo catalyzed of ZnOwere suggested as one of the primary antibacterialmechanisms [13]. Zinc oxide possesses superior intrinsic properties such as a large exciton binding energy of 60 meV at room temperature, high photocatalytic activity, low cost, and environmentally friendly [14]. However, ZnO is awide band gap (3.37 eV) semiconductor, and can absorb the radiation only in theUV region, which is a small portion (4%) of the solar spectrum [14]. The photocatalytic properties of ZnO in the visible region can be improved by dopingwithmetal
© 2019 IOPPublishing Ltd
such as silver (Ag) and gold (Au), which are themost useful because of its high stability and good thermal/ electrical conductivity. Schottky junction arising from semiconductor-metal link causes an internal electric field which promotes inmitigation of photo-generated charge carrier recombination [15]. Currently,many researchers areworking on enhancing the efficiency of photocatalytic performance of ZnObecause this mechanism could lead to the generation of strong antimicrobial ability [16]. In the present study, the rawSWNTs and raw-MWNTs have been functionalized and decoratedwithmetal-doped ZnOnanoparticles by using co-precipitationmethod, and their antimicrobial activity againstEscherichia coli and Staphylococcus aureus in the dark and underUV irradiation have been investigated and discussed.

sections.heading: Reagents andmaterials
sections.text: The raw-SWNTs (purity>95 wt%; diameter∼1-4 nm; length∼0.5-2 μm;Ash∼ 15 wt%) and raw-MWNTs (purity>95 wt%; diameter∼8–15 nm; length∼10-50 μm;Ash∼15 wt%)were purchased from cheaptubes. com,Grafton, VT,USA. Silver nitrate (AgNO3, 99.9%), zinc acetate dehydrate (Zn (COOCH3)2.2H2O, 99%), oxalic acid (C2H2O4, 98%), gold chloride trihydrate (HAuCl4.3H2O, 99.9%), and sodium citrate (Na3C6H5O7, 99%)were obtained fromSigma-Aldrich. Other chemicals such as anhydrous ethanol (C2H5OH, 99.9%)were obtained fromSasma, sulfuric acid (H2SO4, 95%) from J.T. Baker, and nitric acid (HNO3, 65%) fromCentral DrugHouse.Mueller-Hinton agar (LAB039) and nutrient agar (LAB008)were provided fromNeogenCulture Media. Bacterial strains, including Staphylococcus aureus andEscherichia coli used in our tests were selected from the collection of the laboratory of Biotechnology, Nanotechnology AdvancedMaterial ResearchCenter, University of Technology, Iraq.

sections.heading: Materials preparation and characterization
sections.text:
Acid treatment of raw-SWNTs and raw-MWNTs In this section, 500 mg of raw-SWNTswas treatedwith 200 ml of an acidmixture of sulfuric acid and nitric acid (3:1 v/v) to produceOH- and/orCOOH functionalized-SWNTs. Themixture was placed in an ultrasonic bath at 30 °C for 40 min, then dilutedwith distilledwater, vacuum-filtered through a 0.22 μmcellulose nitrate membrane, and dried at 100 °C for 12 h. The same procedure was repeated for raw-MWNTs to synthesize functionalized-MWNTs.
Synthesis of ZnO/AgNPs coated SWNTs andMWNTs First, 500 mg of zinc acetate dehydrate and silver nitrate (Ag/Zn=10% inmole ratio)was dissolved in 50 ml of anhydrous ethanol. The functionalized-SWNTs (200 mg) has been added into amixture under sonication for 15 min.One gramof oxalic acid dissolved in 50 ml of anhydrous ethanol, then slowly dropped into themixture solution of zinc acetate dehydrate and silver nitrate. Themixed solutionwas stirred at the 60 °C for 1 h and dried at the 80 °C for two days. Finally, themixturewas calcinated at 450 °C for 2 h in atmospheric pressure to obtain powder of SWNTs/ZnO-Ag. The same procedure was repeated for functionalized-MWNTs to prepare MWNTs/ZnO–Ag.
Synthesis of ZnO/AuNPs coated SWNTs andMWNTs Briefly, 100 mg of ZnOnanoparticles and 200 mg functionalized-SWNTswere dispersed in 50 ml of distilled water. To prepare goldNPs solution, 30 mg gold chloride (Au/Zn=10% inmole ratio)was dispersed in 50 ml of distilledwater and heated to boiling temperature. The ZnO-SWNTs solutionwas added to the goldNPs solution and stirred for 1 h. Afterwards, temperature, turn off and 10 ml of an aqueous 0.02 M sodium citrate solutionwas added and continuously stirred for another 2 h. Themixturewas left for 24 h to precipitate, then washedwith distilledwater,filtered, and dried at 100 °C for 12 h to obtain powder of SWNTs/ZnO–Au. The same procedure was repeated for functionalized-MWNTs to prepareMWNTs/ZnO–Au.

sections.heading: Instruments
sections.text: The structural properties were investigated by x-ray diffraction (XRD, Shimadzu)withCuKα (λ=0.15405 nm) inNanotechnology AdvancedMaterial ResearchCenter, University of Technology, Iraq. The optical properties were studied byUV-vis spectrophotometer (Lambda 750, Perkin Elmer) inUniversity of Technology, Iraq. The morphological properties were characterized viafield emission scanning electronmicroscope (FESEM,Mira 3-XMU) and transmission electronmicroscopic (TEM, EM208, Philips) inDay Petronic Co. Tehran, Iran . Qualitative analysis of compositionwas performed via energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS, analyzer connected to FESEM instrument).

sections.heading: Antimicrobial test
sections.text:
Determination of viable cells number The number of viable cells wasmeasured by using the traditional platingmethod [17]. The S. aureus andE. coli were grown onMueller-Hinton agar incubated at 37 °C for 24 h. The hybrid samples (SWNT/ZnO-Ag, SWNTs/ZnO-Au,MWNTs/ZnO-Ag orMWNTs/ZnO-Au)with concentration 1 mgmL−1 were dissolved in 9 ml of distilledwater and sterilized in an autoclave at 120 °C for 30 min before used. Bacterial suspension has been adjusted to obtain cell samples with initial concentrations about 107 CFU/mLandmatchwith the McFarland turbidity standard. Then, 1 ml of bacterial suspension has been added into the samples and exposed toUV radiation (8W, 365 nmwavelength, Philips) for 2 h at room temperature. Themixed samples-cell were kept in a shaker incubator at 37 °C (160 rpm) for 30 min. The suspensions of 1 ml of the samples-cell have been serially dilutedwith distilledwater (1:1000). The viable cell number in each sample wasmeasured by spreading of 100 μl of the dilution ontoNutrient agar plate for aerobic incubation at 37 °C. After one day, colonies on each plate were counted and viable cell number was evaluated as colony forming units permilliliter (CFUmL−1). The same procedure was repeated tomeasure the number of viable cells without usingUV radiation.
The percentage reductions of bacteria have been estimated by using the bactericidal rate K [18]:
= - ´ ( ) ( )K A B
A 100 % 1
where A andB represented the numbers of bacteria corresponding to the control plates and sample plates, respectively.

sections.heading: Fluorescence imaging
sections.text: Thefluorescencemicroscope has been used to image the dead and live bacterial cells treatedwith hybrid samples. To distinguish the dead cells from live ones, Acridine orange/Ethidiumbromide (AO/BO) staining assaywas used for cell viability. AcridineOrangefluoresces green stained live cells while EthidiumBromide fluoresces red stained dead cells [19]. About 50 μl of cells-samples suspensionwasmixedwith 50 μl of the (AO/ BO) double fluorescent dyemixture at concentration 10 μg ml−1 for 5 min. Afterwards, a drop of themixture was spread on amicroscopic glass slide, and fluorescent images were taken instantly with thefluorescence microscope (Meiji Techno. Co., Ltd,MT6300).

sections.heading: Structural analysis
sections.text:
TheXRDpatterns for ZnO/Ag andZnO/Audecorated on SWNTs andMWNTs by the chemical precipitation method are shown infigure 1. All samples are polycrystallinewithwurtzite zinc oxide phase. The highly intense (100), (002), (101), (102), and (110) peaks can be ascribed to crystalline ZnOwith the hexagonal structure (JCPDS cardNo. 36-1451) [20]. Also, the four diffraction peaks corresponding to the planes (111), (200), (220), and (331), which confirmed the face-centered cubic phase ofmetallic silver (JCPDS cardNo. 04-0783) and gold nanoparticles (JCPDS cardNo. 04-0784) [21, 22]. A decrease in the peak position ismostly noticedwhen a dopingmetal with a larger ionic radius comparedwith ZnO ion is replaced at the substitution sites of the zinc
oxide nanostructure lattice. Ag+ ion (1.22 Å) andAu+ ion (1.37) have a higher ionic size than a Zn2+ ion (0.74 Å), maybe replacing Zn2+ ions, and the presence of silver and gold diffraction peaks in theXRDpatterns obviously indicates the formation of crystallinemetallic clusters in the nanostructure samples [23]. The Additional (002) diffraction plane are associated to the SWNTs andMWNTs, which are characteristic to graphitic backbone nanostructure (JCPDS cardNo. 01-0646) [24]. The (002) diffraction peaks of SWNTs and MWNTs in the samples are shifted to higher diffraction angle in comparisonwith the raw-SWNTs and rawMWNTs as demonstrated infigure 2. This reveals that an interlayer distance (d) decreases after deposition of nanoparticles on theCNTs. This shift is often developed from the strong interaction betweenNPs and carbon nanotubes. Besides, this interactionmay consequence in compressive stress, giving rise to reduce in interlayer distance. FromXRDdata and by using theDebye-Scherer formula [25],
l q = ( )k B cos L 2
The crystallite size of ZnOwas estimated to be around 12 to 16 nmas shown in table 1. From the results, it can be deduced that the crystallite size decreased by themetal doping, which are in agreementwith that of previous studies [26].

sections.heading: Optical analysis
sections.text:
The absorption spectra of hybrid samples recorded as a function of wavelength in the range of 200 nm to 800 nm at room temperature are shown infigure 3. All samples display a characteristic absorption band centered at maximum intensity of spectra, which are associatedwithπ–π* electronic transition inC=Cbonds of carbon nanotube structure. The attachment of ZnO/Ag andZnO/Aunanoparticles withCNTs causes shifting in absorption edge toward the higher wavelength (red shift).More number of nanoparticles are decorated into CNTs and theseNPs rest on the surface andmaking the surface areamore and exhibiting plasmonic resonance peak in theUV-vis spectra. This shift in absorption spectra is caused by the electronic interaction ofmolecular orbitals between nanoparticles and carbon nanotubes, constructing a newmolecular orbital and reducing the band difference [27]. Figure 4 depicts the relationship between (αhν)2 and an energy of a photon (hν) have been plotted fromTauc equation [28].
a u = u -( ) ( )/h K h Eg 31 2
The energy gaps values of samples are lower than that pure ZnO reported in previous work [29], as shown in table 2. Decreasing the optical band gap can be attributed to the Ag+was substituted into the Zn2+ sites that confirmed byXRD results.Metal doping in ZnOprovides the impurity level in the energy gap because of the formation of the p-type in doped samples.

sections.heading: Morphological analysis
sections.text:
Figure 5 depicts the compositional EDS analysis of raw-MWNTs, raw-SWNTs, and hybrid samples. A strong carbon peak andweak oxygen peak have been detected in raw-MWNTs and raw-SWNTs. The EDS spectra of
metal-doped ZnOdeposited onMWNTs and SWNTs reveal the existence of Zn,O,metal (Ag/Au), and theC element as shown in table 3. As expected, EDS spectra confirm that the nanoparticles deposited on the surface of MWNTs and SWNTs aremetal-doped ZnOnanoparticles.
The shape andmorphology of all samples were performed by both FESEMandTEManalyses. The inset of figures 5(a) and (b)presents FESEMmicrograph of raw-MWNTs, raw-SWNTs, andmetal-doped ZnO deposited onMWNTs and SWNTs. It can be easily found that raw-MWNTs and raw-SWNTs images reveal tangled tubes like bundles (with diameter vary from20 to 80 nm), due toVan derWaals force exists between tubes. Figure 5(c)–(f) shows themetal/ZnOdeposited onMWNTs and SWNTs images reveal that almost
sphericalmetal/ZnOnanoparticles with various size distributions, arewell attached toCNTswalls through chemical precipitationmethod.
Figures 6(a) and (b) shows TEM images of raw-MWNTs and raw-SWNTs. It can be seen from thisfigure, long nanotubes with relativelywell graphitizedwalls and bending tubeswere investigated, and they caused
self-aggregation. Comparedwith the TEM images of raw-MWNTs and raw-SWNTs, the surface ofMWNTs and SWNTswere observed to be uniformly distributedwith nanoparticles as shown infigures 6(c)–(f), which confirmed anchoring of nanoparticles onCNTs by simplemixing. The results of quantitative analysis with EDS andTEM images verified thatmetal-doped ZnOwas successfully supported onMWNTs and SWNTs.

sections.heading: Antimicrobial test results
sections.text:
The colony forming unit assay has been used to evaluate the antimicrobial activity on different types of hybrid samples againstE. coli as gram-negative and S. aureus as gram-positive pathogenic bacteria. Figure 7 and 8 show colonies number ofE. coli and S. aureus respectively, after incubation in the dark at 37 °C for 24 h and underUV
irradiation at room temperature for 2 h. The obtained results display that all samples show significant inhibitory effect towards bothE. coli and S. aureus bacteria. A few bacterial colonies have been presented, indicating that high antimicrobial activity of the all samples. Thisfinding proposes that the inhibition of bacterial growth of the samplesmight be synergistic effect caused by both themetal-doped ZnOnanoparticles and carbon nanotubes. First, for the case of CNTs, possiblemechanismof antimicrobial performance ofMWNTs and SWNTswas suggested as follows: bacterial cellmembrane rupture by direct contact; formation of cell-CNTs aggregates; oxidation of the bacterialmembrane by effective electrostatic force betweenCNTs and bacterial outer surface [30]. Second, for the case of nanoparticles, NPs interactionwith the cellmembrane of bacteria then reacts with proteins by getting adhering to the thiol group and the proteins get inactivated. In this case, duplication process of bacteria decreases as well asmembrane integrity gets harmed. Some nanoparticlesmay release ionswhich permeate the bacteria cell and disrupt theDNA, or attack the respiratory chain, finally resulting in cell death [31].
TheUV irradiation improves antimicrobial activity of all samples against bothE. coli and S. aureus bacteria, as shown infigure 9. The viable cell numbers have been decreasing for all samples after irradiationwithUV light for 2 h. The photocatalyst activity of ZnOhas been enhanced byUV illumination, or by dopingwith noble metals asmentioned in previous studies [32, 33]. The reaction of electrons in the conduction bandwith oxygen would produce reactive oxygen species (ROS), which are responsible for the induction oxidative stress of bacteria. In this study, the reactive oxygen speciesmediated by both the functionalized-CNTs and nanoparticles. The oxidative stress resulting fromCNTs due to the presence -OHand -COOHgroups functionalized on the surface, resulting in the formation of the ROS (O2−, OH−, H2O2, etc). Various inhibitionmechanisms can be related to ROS such as alters inmembrane permeability, interactionwith proteins and the interruption of their normal function, interfere withDNAduplication, causingDNAharm, and finally bacteria death [34].
Based on obtaining results, it was obvious that the antimicrobial activity of samples against E. coli bacteria is better than that of S. aureus bacteria. Thismay be from the thinner thickness of the peptidoglycan layer ofE. coli bacteria as compared to that of the S. aureus bacteria, and/or variation inmetabolism and cell physiology [35].
Figure 10 demonstrates the bactericidal rate for E. coli and S. aureus bacteria inactivated bymetal-doped ZnOdeposited on SWNTs andMWNTs. It can be observed that all samples have a high bactericidal rate against two types of bacteria. The enhanced surface area ofNPs-CNTs produced large contact between the bacterial cell membrane andmaterial, resulting in increment of antimicrobial efficacy [36].
To further understand the antimicrobialmechanism of the samples, fluorescencemicroscope has been carried out. TheAO/BOdyes as the indicator of cellmembrane damage have been utilized to estimate the antimicrobial activity of the samples against pathogenic bacteria. Figure 11 shows fluorescencemicroscope images of theE. coli and S. aureus cells treatedwith hybridmaterials. At high numbers of dead cells with red color have been observed comparedwith live cells with green color, which proposed that bacterial cells in the suspension attached to the suspended nanoparticles and form aggregates [37]. The results fromAO/BO staining assay suggested that all prepared samples have high efficiency onmembrane integrity, whichmost of the cells showed in red color because of the loss ofmembrane integrity and react with damage nucleic acid. Thus, the results indicate that the production of ROS on the interaction samples with bacterialmembrane chiefly result in non-viability of bacterial population [38].Moreover, the SWNTs supportedmetal/ZnO sampleswere found to bemore toxic to bacteria thanMWNTs supportedmetal/ZnO. The toxicity of carbon nanotube ismainly affected by diameter, length, residual catalyst, surface functional group, and electronic structure [39]. The shorter tubes (SWNTs∼0.5-2 μm) is founded to extend higher bactericidal performance in comparison to longer tubes (MWNTs∼10-50 μm). Also, the tubeswith small diameter (SWNTs∼1–4)nmmade the bacteria interact closely with each other.While, tubes with large diameter (MWNTs∼15–30 nm) usually interact with bacteria by their sidewalls, where the cells were just situated on top of the carbon nanotubes in place of tightly interactingwith tube bundles [40]. Although the antimicrobial activity of SWNTswas better thanMWNTs, the
prices for production of SWNTsweremore expensive. Since, the economic benefits ofMWNTs are favored than those of SWNTs.

sections.heading: Conclusion
sections.text:
Ag-doped ZnOandAu-doped ZnOnanoparticles have been successfully prepared and decorated on SWNTs andMWNTs by the chemical precipitation process. The obtained results fromXRD, EDS, and electron microscope (FESEM, TEM) verified formation and loading ofmetal-doped ZnOon SWNTs andMWNTs. The colony-forming unit assay and fluorescent image results reveal that the improved antimicrobial activity of the samples has been associatedwith synergistic effect ofmetal/ZnONPs and carbon nanotubes (SWNTs,
MWNTs). In fact, the as-prepared samples have been exhibited a high potential for biomedicine applications due to themutual affect between the large surface area and powerful adsorption property of the CNTs and high bactericidal and catalytic activities of themetal-doped ZnOnanoparticles.

metadata.abstractText: In this work, singlewall nanotubes (SWNTs) andmulti wall nanotubes (MWNTs)have been chemically treatedwith sulfuric acid and nitric acid (3:1 v/v). TheAg-doped ZnO andAu-doped ZnO nanoparticles have been decorated on SWNTs andMWNTs by the chemical precipitationmethod. The hybridmaterials have been characterized via x-ray diffraction (XRD), ultraviolet-visible (UV-vis) spectrophotometer, energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS), and electronmicroscopy (FESEM, TEM). Antimicrobial activity of hybridmaterials has been evaluated by using colony-forming unit assay and fluorescencemicroscope. Escherichia coli (E. coli) asGram-negative and Staphylococcus aureus (S. aureus) asGram-positive have been employed as the target bacterium. All hybridmaterials have been reported to possess strong antimicrobial activity towardsE. coli and S. aureus bacteria, due to synergistic effect betweenmetal-doped ZnOnanoparticles and carbon nanotubes. A high bactericidal rates have been reported for all hybridmaterials incubated in the dark and underUV light. The photocatalytic properties ofmetal-dopedZnOhave been played important role for inhibiting bacterial growth due to generate reactive oxygen species (ROS) causing cellular toxicity.
